document.discussion_title: Plastic in Nemo bubble bath poses threat to marine life | | The Times & The Sunday Times
document.topic_text: If you have any feedback please let us know . Plastic in Nemo bubble bath poses threat to marine life Jon Ungoed-Thomas and Joseph Hook April 24 2016, 1:01am, The Sunday Times The plastic ‘microbeads’ in bath products can wash into the sea and be ingested by marine life Hero Images/Getty A bubble bath promoting Disney’s Finding Nemo — the highest-grossing movie on sealife — is among the bathroom products containing plastic “microbeads” that ­pollute the oceans and harm marine life, a Sunday Times investigation has found. The glittering children’s bubble bath sold at Tesco — ­featuring Nemo the clownfish, a sea turtle and a starfish on the packaging — contains tiny pieces of plastic that end up being washed down the drains into the seas. The microscopic beads are commonly used in bathroom and beauty products as an exfoliant, as glitter, filler or as a bonding agent. Fish and other Want the full article and instant website access?
